content:
This is not a question.

Here I am answering a side quest from @David Egolf 's thread.

Puzzle: Show that the étale space Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) associated with the sheaf FFF of analytic functions on X=RX = \mathbb{R}X=R is also Hausdorff.

The topology on Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is generated by the following base of open subsets. Given (U,s)(U, s)(U,s) with UUU an open subset of XXX, and s∈F(U)s \in F(U)s∈F(U) a section of the analytic sheaf, define [U,s][U, s][U,s] to be the set of germs [sx][s_x][sx​] for all x∈Ux \in Ux∈U. An open set is Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is an arbitrary union of these basic open sets.

Let a,ba, ba,b be two distinct points of Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F). I.e., aaa (resp. bbb) is the germ at xxx (resp. yyy) of some analytic function sss (resp. ttt) with an open domain UUU (resp. VVV)

a=[s]xb=[t]y\begin{align*} a &= [s]_x \\ b &= [t]_y \\ \end{align*}ab​=[s]x​=[t]y​​

Case x≠yx \ne yx=y

First, consider the case x≠yx \ne yx=y. Because X=RX = \mathbb{R}X=R is Hausdorff, there exists two open subsets $U', V'$ such that

x∈U′⊆Uy∈V′⊆VU′∩V′=∅\begin{align*} x \in U' &\subseteq U \\ y \in V' &\subseteq V \\ U' \cap V' &= \emptyset \end{align*}x∈U′y∈V′U′∩V′​⊆U⊆V=∅​

Let A=[U′,s∣U′]A = [U', s_{|U'}]A=[U′,s∣U′​] (resp. B=[V′,t∣V′]B = [V', t_{|V'}]B=[V′,t∣V′​]) be the open subset of Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) associated to the restriction of sss (resp. ttt) to U′U'U′ (resp. V′V'V′). Then

a∈Ab∈BA∩B=∅\begin{align*} a &\in A\\ b &\in B\\ A \cap &B = \emptyset\\ \end{align*}abA∩​∈A∈BB=∅​

Case x=yx = yx=y

Let W=U∩VW = U \cap VW=U∩V, and

A=[W,s∣W]B=[W,t∣W]\begin{align*} A &= [W, s_{|W}] \\ B &= [W, t_{|W}] \\ \end{align*}AB​=[W,s∣W​]=[W,t∣W​]​

Those sets are open neighbourhoods of aaa and bbb respectively.

We claim that A∩B=∅A \cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅. Assume, by contradiction, that there exists a germ c∈A∩Bc \in A \cap Bc∈A∩B. This means that sss and ttt have a common germ ccc at some point z∈Wz \in Wz∈W.

[s]z=[t]z=c[s]_z = [t]_z = c[s]z​=[t]z​=c

In particular, sss and ttt have the same power series at zzz

∑n≥0s(n)(z)(T−z)nn!=∑n≥0t(n)(z)(T−z)nn!\sum_{n\ge0} s^{(n)}(z)\frac{(T - z)^n}{n!} = \sum_{n\ge0} t^{(n)}(z)\frac{(T - z)^n}{n!}n≥0∑​s(n)(z)n!(T−z)n​=n≥0∑​t(n)(z)n!(T−z)n​

Because sss and ttt are analytic functions, this implies that they agree on some open subset of WWW. Moreover, the unicity of analytic continuation implies that sss and ttt actually agree over WWW. Hence

a=[s]x=[t]x=ba = [s]_x = [t]_x = ba=[s]x​=[t]x​=b

But we assumed aaa and bbb to be distinct, whence a contradiction.

Final remarks

The crux of the argument seems to rely on the fact that, for every point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the map

ϕx:Λ(F)x→RN[s]x↦(s(x),s(1)(x),s(2)(x),… )\begin{align*} \phi_x : \Lambda(F)_x &\rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{\mathbb{N}} \\ [s]_x &\mapsto (s(x), s^{(1)}(x), s^{(2)}(x), \dots) \end{align*}ϕx​:Λ(F)x​[s]x​​→RN↦(s(x),s(1)(x),s(2)(x),…)​

is injective.

Now, I am wondering if this injectiveness characterizes the Hausdorff property.

Let's consider an arbitrary sheaf FFF over R\mathbb{R}R, for which there is a way to make sense of the ϕx\phi_xϕx​'s (e.g., maybe a sub-sheaf of some sheaf of distributions).

Can we prove that the proposition "Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is Hausdorff" is equivalent to "the ϕx\phi_xϕx​'s are all injective"?

The only problem with proving a general proposition like that is that for an arbitrary sheaf FFF on R\mathbb{R}R we don't have any natural way to define the ϕx\phi_xϕx​ functions. We could try to study which sheaves do have such functions, and then try to prove the proposition you want. But I think there's a necessary and sufficient condition for Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) to be Hausdorff which is very general, simple to state, and easy to prove! It's this:

Conjecture. Suppose FFF is sheaf on a topological space XXX. Then Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is Hausdorff if and only if for every open U⊆XU \subseteq XU⊆X and every s1,s2∈Λ(U)s_1, s_2 \in \Lambda(U)s1​,s2​∈Λ(U), the set of points x∈Ux \in Ux∈U for which the germ of s1s_1s1​ equals the germ of s2s_2s2​ is closed in UUU.
I'm calling it a conjecture because I haven't checked it, but a special case is proved here.

In the case where FFF is the sheaf of analytic functions on R\mathbb{R}R, we use the conjecture by showing that for any two analytic functions defined on some open set U⊆RU \subseteq \mathbb{R}U⊆R, the set on which their germs are equal is closed in UUU. The conjecture then implies Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is Hausdorff.

In the case where FFF is the sheaf of smooth functions on R\mathbb{R}R, we use the conjecture by finding two smooth functions on R\mathbb{R}R for which the set on which their germs are equal is not closed. We can use the function 000 and the function

f(x)={0if x≤0e−1x2otherwise f(x) = \begin{cases} 0 &\text{if } x \le 0 \\ e^{-\frac{1}{x^2}} &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}f(x)={0e−x21​​if x≤0otherwise​

We can check that these two functions have equal germs at xxx for x<0x \lt 0x<0, but different germs for x≥0x \ge 0x≥0.

The conjecture then implies that Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is not Hausdorff.

This proposition is way more neat, indeed!

Here is a proof (I think).

Forward direction

Assume Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is Hausdorff. Let

D={x∈U∣[s]x≠[t]x} D = \{ x\in U | [s]_x \ne [t]_x \}D={x∈U∣[s]x​=[t]x​}

We show that DDD is open. Fix x∈Dx \in Dx∈D. Since Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is Hausdorff, there exists two disjoint open subsets S,T⊆Λ(F)S, T \subseteq \Lambda(F)S,T⊆Λ(F) such that

[s]x∈S[t]x∈TS∩T=∅\begin{align*} [s]_x &\in S \\ [t]_x &\in T \\ S \cap &T = \emptyset \end{align*}[s]x​[t]x​S∩​∈S∈TT=∅​

By definition of the topology on Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F), this implies that there exists open neighborhoods V,W⊆UV, W \subseteq UV,W⊆U of xxx such that

[s]x∈[V,s∣V][t]x∈[W,t∣W][V,s∣V]∩[W,t∣W]=∅\begin{align*} [s]_x &\in [V, s_{|V}] \\ [t]_x &\in [W, t_{|W}] \\ [V, s_{|V}] \cap [W, t_{|W}] &= \emptyset \end{align*}[s]x​[t]x​[V,s∣V​]∩[W,t∣W​]​∈[V,s∣V​]∈[W,t∣W​]=∅​

The last condition further implies that

[V∩W,s∣V∩W]∩[V∩W,t∣V∩W]=∅[V \cap W, s_{|V \cap W}] \cap [V \cap W, t_{|V \cap W}] = \emptyset[V∩W,s∣V∩W​]∩[V∩W,t∣V∩W​]=∅

In other words, x∈V∩W⊆Dx \in V \cap W \subseteq Dx∈V∩W⊆D. I.e., DDD is open.

Reverse direction

Assume that for any open subset UUU, for any sections s,t∈F(U)s, t \in F(U)s,t∈F(U), the set {x∈U ∣ [s]x≠[t]x}\{ x \in U ~|~ [s]_x \ne [t]_x \}{x∈U ∣ [s]x​=[t]x​} is open. We prove that Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is Hausdorff.

Fix two germs a=[s]xa = [s]_xa=[s]x​ and b=[t]yb = [t]_yb=[t]y​ in Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F), and assume that they are distinct, a≠ba \ne ba=b.

If x≠yx \ne yx=y, then, since XXX is Hausdorff, there exists two disjoint open subsets V,WV, WV,W containing xxx and yyy respectively. Then

[V∩dom(s),s∣V∩dom(s)] is an open neighborhood of a[W∩dom(t),t∣W∩dom(t)] is an open neighborhood of b\begin{align*} [V \cap dom(s), s_{| V \cap dom(s)}] &\text{ is an open neighborhood of } a\\ [W \cap dom(t), t_{| W \cap dom(t)}] &\text{ is an open neighborhood of } b\\ \end{align*}[V∩dom(s),s∣V∩dom(s)​][W∩dom(t),t∣W∩dom(t)​]​ is an open neighborhood of a is an open neighborhood of b​

Because VVV and WWW are disjoint, these open sets are also disjoint.

Assume now that x=yx = yx=y. Let D={x∈U ∣ [s]x≠[t]x}D = \{ x \in U ~|~ [s]_x \ne [t]_x\}D={x∈U ∣ [s]x​=[t]x​}. Then x∈Dx \in Dx∈D. Since DDD is open, there exists an open neighborhood V⊆DV \subseteq DV⊆D of xxx. Then

[V∩dom(s),s∣V∩dom(s)] is an open neighborhood of a[V∩dom(t),s∣V∩dom(t)] is an open neighborhood of b\begin{align*} [V \cap dom(s), s_{|V\cap dom(s)}] &\text{ is an open neighborhood of } a\\ [V \cap dom(t), s_{|V\cap dom(t)}] &\text{ is an open neighborhood of } b\\ \end{align*}[V∩dom(s),s∣V∩dom(s)​][V∩dom(t),s∣V∩dom(t)​]​ is an open neighborhood of a is an open neighborhood of b​

and, by definition of DDD, these two open subsets of Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) are disjoint.

Therefore, Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) is Hausdorff.

I think my wanderings about analytic functions and stuff is due to the fact that I was trying to capture the argument "if a property PPP is true at some point xxx, then it is true on a neighborhood of xxx".

But this is actually pure topology: this argument is true exactly when the subset characterized by PPP is open w.r.t to the topology of XXX.

Peva Blanchard said:

[s]x∈[V,s∣V][t]x∈[W,t∣W][V,s∣V]∩[W,t∣W]=∅\begin{align*} [s]_x &\in [V, s_{|V}] \\ [t]_x &\in [W, t_{|W}] \\ [V, s_{|V}] \cap [W, t_{|W}] &= \emptyset \end{align*}[s]x​[t]x​[V,s∣V​]∩[W,t∣W​]​∈[V,s∣V​]∈[W,t∣W​]=∅​

What does this notation [V,s∣V][V, s_{|V}][V,s∣V​] mean?

My guess is that [V,s∣V][V,s_{|V}][V,s∣V​] means the open set in Λ(F)\Lambda(F)Λ(F) given by the set of all the germs of sss when it is restricted to VVV. So, I guess that it is what I've been calling g(s)(V)g(s)(V)g(s)(V).
